newsitem.title: PHILIPPINES: Manila says hopes Jakarta will clear Guzman riddle.
newsitem.headline: Manila says hopes Jakarta will clear Guzman riddle.

text.p: Philippines President Fidel Ramos said on Wednesday he had full confidence Indonesia would unravel the mystery surrounding the death of a Filipino geologist who helped discover the controversial Busang gold property.

He said he was sure Indonesian authorities would transmit to the Philippine government the full results of their investigation into the fall from a helicopter last month of Michael de Guzman, chief geologist for Canadian firm Bre-X Minerals Ltd.
Some Indonesian officials have said de Guzman's death appeared to be a suicide but his family in Manila said they doubted he would take his own life.
"We are awaiting the official report of the Indonesian government in which we have full confidence in unravelling mystery," Ramos told his weekly news conference.

Asked if the government had received any report that would suggest de Guzman's death was other than suicide, Ramos said: "None yet because the investigation by the Indonesian government is not complete."
De Guzman helped discover in the Busang jungles on Borneo island what Bre-X at first said were gold reserves estimated at 70.95 million ounces, worth $25 billion at current prices.
That would make the discovery the biggest gold strike in the world this century.
De Guzman's plunge from a helicopter flying him to the gold site and a statement by Bre-X that it was possible the amount of gold at the property had been overstated shocked the mining world.
Bre-X has a 45 percent stake in Busang, while its partner, Freeport McMoran Copper and Gold Inc of the United States holds 15 percent. Indonesian interests hold the rest.
Indonesian and Philippine investigators have carried out two separate autopsies on de Guzman's remains.
A brother of de Guzman said on Monday the family had not yet received the results of the investigation but promised to make them public.
